Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2013 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Andrew Lawrie is "Nonlinear Dispersive Partial Differential Equations with a Focus on Wave Maps." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of California-Berkeley, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Daniel Tataru.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 9/13--8/16 the PI was supported by an NSF Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Fellowship DMS-1302782, titled ``Nonlinear Dispersive Partial Differential Equations with a Focus on Wave Maps," with a total of $150,000. During the tenure of the award the PI authored and co-authored twelve research papers, all published or accepted to appear in highly selective mathematical journals.  

The PI's research broke new ground in the field of nonlinear wave equations, highlighted by the PI's discovery of meta-stable states for geometric waves propagating on a negatively curved background. This phenomena was unexpected by both the mathematics and physics communities and has significantly changed our understanding of how the self-interference of waves interacts with the medium on which they are propagating. The PI's research in this direction has opened doors to many new and exciting problems in the field. In addition, the PI developed several sophisticated new mathematical techniques that have helped further our understranding of wave propagation in settings where it is energetically favorable for a wave to form a singularity by concentration. Such "energy-supercritical" waves appear in a number of fundamental physical models, such as Einstein's equations of general relativity. Depite their importance, there is much still to learn about the possible dynamics, and the PI's work has provided the broader scientific community with a promising direction forward.
